docs.abstract: Smaller amusement parks have added restaurants, shops and hotels to take advantage of a strategy that dates back to the 1960s: Get visitors to stay longer.
docs.snippet: Smaller amusement parks have added restaurants, shops and hotels to take advantage of a strategy that dates back to the 1960s: Get visitors to stay longer.
docs.lead_paragraph: GOSHEN, N.Y. — Merlin Entertainments, the British entertainment company with attractions all over the globe, sees this bucolic town in New York’s Hudson Valley as the perfect spot to build its most ambitious and expensive project: the world’s largest Legoland theme park.

headline.main: From Day Trips to Sleepovers: How Regional Theme Parks Are Evolving
headline.print_headline: Smaller Theme Parks’ Pitch: Stay Longer Than a Day

docs.abstract: The company, citing a human rights report it commissioned, said it was moving to prevent further abuses of its platform in Myanmar. Critics said they were unconvinced.
docs.snippet: The company, citing a human rights report it commissioned, said it was moving to prevent further abuses of its platform in Myanmar. Critics said they were unconvinced.
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook has long promoted itself as a tool for bringing people together to make the world a better place. Now the social media giant has acknowledged that in Myanmar it did the opposite, and human rights groups say it has a lot of work to do to fix that.

headline.main: Facebook Admits It Was Used to Incite Violence in Myanmar
headline.print_headline: Facebook Admits Role Platform Had in Fueling Violence in Myanmar

docs.abstract: A vague statement of disapproval from Fox News did not conceal how the network’s biggest star has gone from pundit to political player.
docs.snippet: A vague statement of disapproval from Fox News did not conceal how the network’s biggest star has gone from pundit to political player.
docs.lead_paragraph: At 11:02 a.m. on Monday, after the Donald J. Trump for President campaign announced that Sean Hannity would appear at his rally on the eve of the midterm elections, the prime-time star of Fox News posted a Shermanesque tweet: “I will not be on the stage campaigning with the president.”

headline.main: Sean Hannity Erased a Line by Taking the Stage With Trump
headline.print_headline: Sharing Trump’s Stage, Fox News Stars Flout An Ideal for Journalists

docs.abstract: An hour-by-hour guide showing how anchors and political pundits across the ideological spectrum grappled with a topsy-turvy night.
docs.snippet: An hour-by-hour guide showing how anchors and political pundits across the ideological spectrum grappled with a topsy-turvy night.
docs.lead_paragraph: An hour-by-hour guide showing how anchors and political pundits across the ideological spectrum grappled with a topsy-turvy night.

headline.main: How CNN, Fox News and MSNBC Covered the Midterm Elections

byline.original: By Jaclyn Peiser, Zach Wichter and Tiffany Hsu

docs.abstract: Early on, CNN’s Van Jones called it a “heartbreaking” night for liberals. Then came a bold projection from an unlikely source.
docs.snippet: Early on, CNN’s Van Jones called it a “heartbreaking” night for liberals. Then came a bold projection from an unlikely source.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get live election analysis and real-time results.

headline.main: Wary Networks Dawdled on House Call, Until Fox News Led the Way
headline.print_headline: Headlines of Good News for Democrats, but From an Unlikely Source

docs.abstract: The authors of a new academic study explore the effect of political differences on how we give to charity.
docs.snippet: The authors of a new academic study explore the effect of political differences on how we give to charity.
docs.lead_paragraph: Many issues seem to divide Democrats and Republicans, and new research has found one more: philanthropy.

headline.main: How Political Ideology Influences Charitable Giving

docs.abstract: Facebook has had a turbulent two years. But almost no one in tech thinks Mr. Zuckerberg, the social network’s chief executive, should step down from the company he built.
docs.snippet: Facebook has had a turbulent two years. But almost no one in tech thinks Mr. Zuckerberg, the social network’s chief executive, should step down from the company he built.
docs.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, after Facebook revealed that tens of millions of its users’ accounts had been exposed in a security breach, I began asking people in and around the tech industry a simple question: Should Mark Zuckerberg still be running Facebook?

headline.main: How Mark Zuckerberg Became Too Big to Fail
headline.print_headline: How Mark Zuckerberg Became Too Big to Fail

docs.abstract: Amazon defied expectations by splitting its second headquarters into two locations. For the internet company, it seems to be working out rather nicely.
docs.snippet: Amazon defied expectations by splitting its second headquarters into two locations. For the internet company, it seems to be working out rather nicely.

headline.main: Was Amazon’s Headquarters Contest a Bait-and-Switch? Critics Say Yes
headline.print_headline: A Ruse or Brilliant Marketing by Amazon? Yes

docs.abstract: The 16 new trademarks cover a broad array of goods and services, including purses, swimsuits, fire extinguishers and senior citizens’ homes.
docs.snippet: The 16 new trademarks cover a broad array of goods and services, including purses, swimsuits, fire extinguishers and senior citizens’ homes.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China granted initial approval for 16 new trademarks to Ivanka Trump, the president’s elder daughter and senior adviser, renewing questions about the Trump family’s intermingling of official roles and international business interests.

headline.main: China Grants Ivanka Trump Initial Approval for New Trademarks
headline.print_headline: Ivanka Trump Gets China’s Nod for 16 More Trademarks

docs.abstract: Stocks, which rallied Monday on the potential for a truce in the United States-China trade war, began a downward spiral on Tuesday as confusion set in about whether an agreement had truly been reached.
docs.snippet: Stocks, which rallied Monday on the potential for a truce in the United States-China trade war, began a downward spiral on Tuesday as confusion set in about whether an agreement had truly been reached.
docs.lead_paragraph: The trade war is back on — at least as far as investors are concerned.

headline.main: Trump Warns China That He’s ‘Tariff Man,’ Spooking Stock Investors
headline.print_headline: Markets Dive After ‘Tariff Man’ Threat by Trump

byline.original: By Matt Phillips and Alan Rappeport
